message_1: In a substitution cipher, each letter in the alphabet is replaced with another letter. If a message encrypted with a substitution cipher reads "lwklqjv vwulqj", which was encrypted with a Caesar cipher (a type of substitution cipher that shifts each letter by a certain number of places in the alphabet), what is the actual message? (Hint: the key used in the Caesar cipher is a shift of 3.)
message_2:
To decrypt the message "lwklqjv vwulqj" encrypted with a Caesar cipher with a shift of 3, we need to shift each letter back by 3 positions in the alphabet.

l -> i
w -> t
k -> h
l -> i
q -> n
j -> g
v -> s

v -> s
w -> t
u -> r
l -> i
q -> n
j -> g

The decrypted message is "ithings string".
